description:
The Torque teno mini virus 10 (TTMnV-10) is a small, non-enveloped DNA virus that belongs to the family Anelloviridae. It is a member of the genus Betatorquevirus, which includes several other torque teno mini virus (TTMnV) species.

TTMnV-10 has a circular, single-stranded DNA genome of approximately 2.8 kilobases in size. The viral genome encodes a limited number of proteins, including the viral capsid protein responsible for the virus's structural integrity.

TTMnV-10 is primarily found in human and animal populations, with a widespread global distribution. The virus is considered a commensal or opportunistic pathogen, meaning it can be present in healthy individuals without causing any overt clinical symptoms.

The transmission dynamics and potential pathogenic role of TTMnV-10 are not yet fully understood. However, studies suggest that the virus may be associated with certain disease conditions, particularly in immunocompromised or immunosuppressed individuals, where it may contribute to or exacerbate underlying health issues.

Further research is needed to elucidate the precise ecological and clinical significance of TTMnV-10 in human and animal health, as well as its potential interactions with other infectious agents or host factors.
